node.title: Applicability of MOOSE electrical module in PLASMA flow control
node.bodyText:
Dear researchers and developers,
thank you guys so much for providing the open-source PLASMA simulation codes. I am a novice in PLASMA research and working hard to complete my doctoral studies.However, due to my poor ability on programming of finite element solvers, it has been hard to complete the simulation code of PLASMA completely on my own. To be honest, I was very excited when I first saw Zapdos. I thought it might help me to supplement my lack of simulation.
To get back to the point, I hope to use Zapdos to complete the simulation work in the literature[1], but unfortunately, due to a lack of understanding of the underlying solver, I am unable to make a judgment on whether Zapdos can correctly complete this simulation process. I am eager to receive your answers on the applicability of the Zapdos underlying solver to the simulation of PLASMA flow control actuators. If the work can proceed, I also hope to include the reference of Zapdos in my own paper when publishing articles in the future. Thank you so much. The reference is attached in the email.
Reference
[1]Kunwar Pal Singh, Subrata Roy; Modeling plasma actuators with air chemistry for effective flow control. Journal of Applied Physics 15 June 2007; 101 (12): 123308. https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2749467
Hi @Badtreater as your question is more about Zapdos, can you open a discussion on the Zapdos repository? https://github.com/shannon-lab/zapdos/discussions

node.title: AD Dynamics Issues
node.bodyText:
A previous discussion reminded me a weird issues I have had with AD and Dynamics in MOOSE. Let know if I didn't set something up correctly and that led me to these problems!  Issue 1 is makes me worry that I am just missing something simple.
Issue 1: ADIntertial Force
beta = 0.25
gamma = 0.5

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmax = 0.30
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 15
    ny = 25
    elem_type = QUAD4
    boundary_name_prefix = flexible
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = false
  []
[]

[Kernels]
    [inertia_x]
      type = ADInertialForce #Converting to InertialForce will fix this problem
      variable = disp_x
    []
    [inertia_y]
      type = ADInertialForce #Converting to InertialForce will fix this problem
      variable = disp_y
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elastic_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e+4
    poissons_ratio = 0.4
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [density]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial # Convert to Generic
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [hold_x]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []
  [hold_y]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [Pressure]
    [push]
      function = 50 # This can be set to as low as 1e-4 and still cause problems 
      boundary = 'flexible_left '
      use_automatic_differentiation = true
      use_displaced_mesh = true
    []
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 1
  dt = 1e-2
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason '
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_shift_amount'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  NONZERO 1e-15'

  line_search = 'none'
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-7
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6

  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    beta = ${beta}
    gamma = ${gamma}
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  file_base = "ad"
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]


AD Convergence (input file above): Solve doesn't converge, time drops until errors out.
Even If you set nl_forced_its = 5 and the pressure to even 1e-8, the solution will not converge. Need the nl_forced_its to keep it from converging before Newton Loops.
Time Step 1, time = 0.01, dt = 0.01
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 4.924429e+00
  Linear solve converged due to CONVERGED_RTOL iterations 1

  Linear solve converged due to CONVERGED_RTOL iterations 1

  Linear solve converged due to CONVERGED_RTOL iterations 1

Cannot take square root of a number less than or equal to zero in the calculation of C3_test for the Rashid approximation for the rotation tensor. This zero or negative number may occur when elements become heavily distorted.
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 3

Aborting as solve did not converge

Converting ADInertialForce to InertialForce (along with density to generic)

Time Step 1, time = 0.01, dt = 0.01

  Linear solve converged due to CONVERGED_RTOL iterations 1

  Linear solve converged due to CONVERGED_RTOL iterations 1
 4 Nonlinear |R| = 2.224675e-07
Nonlinear solve converged due to CONVERGED_FNORM_RELATIVE iterations 4
 Solve Converged!

Issue 2:  decomposition_method = EigenSolution with AD
Same problem as before commenting out decomposition_method = EigenSolution will allow for convergence.
beta = 0.25
gamma = 0.5

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmax = 0.30
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 15
    ny = 25

  []

    type = ADComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [hold_x]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []
  [hold_y]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [Pressure]
    [push]
      function = 50
      boundary = 'flexible_left '
      use_automatic_differentiation = true
      use_displaced_mesh = true
    []
  []

  [SMP]
    type = SMP

  []

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6

[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus

For case 2: using the action below to replace the Kernel and "Master" action will also cause convergence problems that don't exist with the nonAD version.
[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    decomposition_method = EigenSolution #Using TaylorExpansion Works
    add_variables = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = true
  []
[]

For 1, is the density scaling important in IntertialForce? and does it depend on nonlinear variables? It s always retrieved as non AD in the kernel.
There's also a time derivative that is always non AD in that kernel (even for the AD version), could be worth investigating
ya the _u_dotdot_factor is non-AD so the AD version of this kernel misses all the Jacobians, I think. @dschwen converted this kernel to AD I believe.
Thanks for reporting @maxnezdyur  I ll create an issue

Perfect! For issue 2: without a damper I get the below convergence behavior,
Time Step 1, time = 0.1, dt = 0.1
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 4.924429e+00

but just using damper we get the below convergence behaviour. I don't know if the AD version is creating a "bad" Jacobain on the first iteration that is just causing too large of a skewed element. By "bad" I think if there is some non-smooth areas then AD can mess up and that's what I think could be happening here. I am not well-versed in AD so take with a grain of salt!
Time Step 1, time = 0.1, dt = 0.1

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]

oh my bad then it must be a separate issue

I'm a bit confused. You had AD/non-AD, damper/no-damper, EigenSolution/TaylorExpansion. I lost track of which combination works and which doesn't.

node.title: How to install a specified version of MOOSE?
node.bodyText:
Reason
Due to certain special reasons, I would like to install a specific version of MOOSE, especially the old version (with modified InputParameter template).
I searched some issues and found the Issue #21548.
The questioner attempted to use the git command to return the version but encountered some problems. I sent a private message to him, and he said that he still hasn't solved the problem.
And I also found there are several versions in the Release Page, but I can not find some install tutorials about them.
So I still have not a good idea about it, and I hope the official can provide relevant tutorials for the users, please!
If this type of tutorial needs to be tailored to different versions, please prioritize providing some guidance for that version snapshot-20-10-27.
Thank you!!!

hello
A discussions post is more appropriate here, I converted it.
You can do this easily by checking out an earlier commit with git checkout <commit_hash>
Do you have a link to this branch? snapshot-20-10-27
I can advise you on the commit from there.
Note that we do not recommend doing this at all. You will miss out on years of bug fixes.
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer. I took your advice. So I took these steps as follow:

(moose_old) lmh@ubuntu:~/projects$ git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose && git checkout b57161c
git clean -nxfd && git clean -xfd && scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
It prompts that  “If you did not run the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script yet, please run it before building libMesh”
So I took the next.
scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
It prompts that "python3 is missing distutils.sysconfig, Skipping...
Error! Could not locate Python (with distutils.sysconfig)! Please install and have python3, python, or python2 (with distutils.sysconfig) in PATH."
So I took the next
sudo apt install python3-pip && sudo pip install disutils
scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
In the end, it prompts a configure mistake about petsc. I put this log file here.
Could you please give me some guidance about it?

configure.log

'InShell' object has no attribute 'isAlive'  File "/home/lmh/projects/moose/petsc/config/configure.py", line 451, in petsc_configure

See this post
jupyter-vim/jupyter-vim#51
you ll need to go rename this call from isAlive to is_alive.
And this is the first of many issues you'll hit by using an old version
what's the issue with using the current MOOSE?

It's entirely possible GCC 11.3.0 (released Apr 2022) is too new a compiler to build this hash of MOOSE. I know this, as we have ran into GCC 11.x issues in the past (a year or so ago).
Ubuntu 22.04 LTS comes with 11.2 (I am not willing to install a non-LTS version, so I will have to stick with 22.04). I am assuming you are using Ubuntu 22.10 or 23.04 (non-LTS versions) (reference: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Releases)? I am only curious if we have to delve into this even more.
I am making points about the version of GCC you are using due to the non-presence of mpicc as described below. I am not sure if you are wanting to use Conda, or your system compilers?
While setting up my environment, I realized the following occurred in your log:
❯ cat configure.log | grep mpicc
Checking for program /home/lmh/projects/moose/python/peacock/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /home/lmh/miniconda3/envs/moose_old/bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /home/lmh/miniconda3/condabin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/local/sbin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/local/bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/sbin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /sbin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/games/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /usr/local/games/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /snap/bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /snap/bin/mpicc...not found
Checking for program /home/lmh/projects/moose/petsc/lib/petsc/bin/win32fe/mpicc...not found
  Unable to find programs ['mpicc'] providing listing of each search directory to help debug

My concerns:
Checking for program /home/lmh/miniconda3/envs/moose_old/bin/mpicc...not found

A moose_old Conda environment still lingers among your PATH. Which in and of itself is odd, that 1, it exists when it possibly should not? And 2, should exist and does not contain an mpicc binary. Maybe this directory has been deleted?
I think the best path forward, is to install the oldest possible moose-mpich moose-tools package we have, and go from there.
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/archive             # An older channel we do not advertise
mamba create -n moose_old moose-tools=2021.07.14 moose-mpich python=3.7 cmake  # overwrite `moose_old`
mamba activate old_mpich
export METHODS=opt METHOD=opt MOOSE_JOBS=6                                     #  to speed up the build process
This above will install an environment which should work with that older version of PETSc you are trying to build...
But as @GiudGiud asked, the absolute best option is to know why you cannot use the latest version of MOOSE?

Thank you for your reply.
I have tried to complete the installation of this version of Moose in the past few days.
I would like to share the specific process.

I installed Python 3.7.6 in the Conda environment(moose_ old ), supplemented with gfortran, bison, and flex.
I ran the script to rebuild petsc using the following command:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh -- download-mpich=1-- download-cmake=1-- with-fc-dir=/usr/bin/gfortran
I ran the script to rebuild libmesh:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_ libmesh.sh

Everything runs well, although there are too many moose tests failed to trigger a warning. I still successfully compiled my previous MooseApp in this version of Moose environment as expected and ran through the example to obtain similar results.
The following are my specific moose environment version for reference.
Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:    git commit b57161c on 2020-10-24
LibMesh Version:   f33331f6ebb0f31dff7526106268ca0c4300049e
PETSc Version:      3.13.3
SLEPc Version:      3.13.3
Next, I will answer your question (why not use the latest moose). I have been developing my own MooseApp in the old version of Moose environment before. Now I want to install the same version of the environment in a new location to run my MooseApp.
In the end, I am curious about some methods you mentioned for installing older versions. Can you provide some pages for placing relevant content on the Moose official website or open up those old installation tutorial pages for reference.
Thank you！

./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh -- download-mpich=1

works for PETSc, but this will not get MPICH for anything except PETSc. You need to provide a system-wide version of MPI instead, so MPI becomes available to libMesh, MOOSE, etc.
Everything will build fine, because libMesh does not require MPI in order to be built. While actually running MOOSE does. So, the errors you are getting when running tests (running moose), are expected.
Ironically, later versions of these scripts your are running have sanity checks in them to alert you, in the event you try to build libMesh without MPI.
Creating instructional pages on how to use older versions of MOOSE is a good idea, but would be problematic. We can only go back so far, and unfortunately in your case, you're going back far enough where we were just beginning to use Conda. We made a lot of mistakes creating those packages back then. So we moved them out from the public channel, into a separate 'archive' channel. That is: they cannot coexist in the same public channel (https://conda.software.inl.gov/public). Doing so causes all sorts of conflicting headaches. Basically what I am trying to say is, even if we created instructions on how to use older versions of MOOSE, the version you want would be beyond the scope of what we'd support showing folks how to do.
For example, in your case, you need to install a version of Python that has reached end of life (https://endoflife.date/python 3.7 is now EOL as of the end of June). When this happens, some maintainers will go so far as to physically remove packages from Conda-Forge (something we cannot prevent).
Going through the instructions I wrote earlier, it would seem all the necessary Conda packages are still available, and everything builds fine for me:
(testing) [ubuntu-22][~/projects/3rd/moose/test]> ./moose_test-opt -h
SLEPc Release Version 3.13.3, unknown

See docs/manual.html for help.
<trimmed>


(testing) [ubuntu-22][~/projects/3rd/moose/test]> git rev-parse HEAD
b57161c312e90a33cf73fcf5f8ce9c0191af6155


(testing) [ubuntu-22][~/projects/3rd/moose/test]> mamba list | grep moose
moose-mpich               3.3.2                   build_7    https://conda.software.inl.gov/archive
moose-tools               2021.07.14       py37hedbaeeb_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/archive


(testing) [ubuntu-22][~/projects/3rd/moose/test]> ./run_tests -j 12
dgkernels/2d_diffusion_dg.no_additional_rms_distributed ........................ [MESH_MODE!=DISTRIBUTED] SKIP
dgkernels/2d_diffusion_dg.proper_ghosting_with_action_serial_distributed ....... [MESH_MODE!=DISTRIBUTED] SKIP
dgkernels/2d_diffusion_dg.proper_ghosting_with_action_parallel_distributed ..... [MESH_MODE!=DISTRIBUTED] SKIP

<trimmed>

materials/derivative_material_interface.ad_mutliblock ..................................................... OK
materials/derivative_material_interface.ad_warn ........................................................... OK
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

node.title: Slow calculation of Jacobian and Residuals in a multi-element tensile test
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I am simulating a simple tensile test in a cube. I am using a UMAT where a plastic model is implemented which depends on the  microstructure evolution defined by different functions. To read the initial particle distribution and the thermal parameters I have implemented the UEXTERNALDB subroutine as well.
My first approach was to use only one element and compare the results and running times with the same ABAQUS model. The MOOSE simulation took less time to finish  and the results were similar. However, I tried to built the cube with 125 elements and now, the MOOSE model takes hours to finish while ABAQUS only needs some minutes. The problems seem to be in some increments where the simulation takes ages to calculate the Jacobian and the residuals as the outputs are:
Computing Jacobian...
Computing initial Residuals....
How could it be this massive difference in times between one single element and 125 elements in MOOSE while ABAQUS can manage it much faster? Is there any way to optimise the building of the Jacobian and the calculation of the Residuals?
Also, I have tried to run the code with different solver types but there is not a significant difference in time.
This is the current input file that I am running:

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin = -0.5
    xmax = 0.5
    ymin = -0.5
    ymax = 0.5
    zmin = -0.5
    zmax = 0.5
    nx = 5
    ny = 5
    nz = 5
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [top_pull]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 0.1*t
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    strain = SMALL
    incremental = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz stress_xy stress_xz stress_yz strain_xx strain_yy strain_zz strain_xy strain_xz strain_yz'

  []
[]

[BCs]
  [y_pull_function]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = top
    function = top_pull
  []
  [x_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0.0
  []
  [y_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  []
  [z_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = front
    value = 0.0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  # 1. active for umat calculation
  [umat]
    type = AbaqusUMATStress
    constant_properties = '210000 0.3 7e10'
    plugin = '../plugins/plastic_MESC_UEXTERNALDB'
    num_state_vars = 300
    use_one_based_indexing = true
  []

In terms of parallelisation, I have run the code using 1 cpu and 4 cpus and I see an important different of times but still very far from the times needed in ABAQUS.

You could try LU preconditioning. Since your system is small it should be fast to form

I'm suggesting this because I see a lot of linear iterations, and if the Jacobian is well formed, LU will only take a single iteration to solve the linear problem.
You ll want to enable this with:
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = 'lu'

(or something close, check the syntax)

Did you build the kernels and BCs yourself or did you use premade ones?

I used premade ones as I am a beginner in MOOSE. I think they are working fine because when I do the simulation with only one element it works fine and even faster than ABAQUS. I do not know, maybe I can try another number of elements or something to see if it is only a problem with this element configuration.

So to troubleshoot failed solves, we have this general page.
In particular, this non-convergence with LU makes me think the Jacobian is wrong / the numerical problem is ill-posed
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/failed_solves.html

oh can you try to either use full = true in the Preconditioning
OR
switch to Newton's method?
We may be trying to solve with only the diagonal of the Jacobian here

Ok the linear solves are now as expected!
now it s just the nonlinear solve that s not converging.
There s a section about that in the troubleshooting page I linked to earlier if you don’t mind trying that

node.title: Tresca yielding criteria
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSEers,
Are there any tresca-yielding-criteria related documents/codes implemented in MOOSE? The plasticity modulus in MOOSE now is using Von-Mises yielding criteria, I want to use Tresca one, how should it be adapted to it? Thanks.

This may be a question for @jasondhales, @bwspenc and @jiangwen84. Before they reply you with a more definitive answer, I think it will be difficult because many classes in the tensor_mechanics are hard-coded with the Mises flow. I often just write a plasticity model from scratch if I need tresca's flow (the radial return utilities are still applicable in that case).
Thanks @hugary1995 , could you kindly share the code of it?  I tried to adapt the von-mises one to Tresca, where I changed the yielding function,  but it seems not work.
@hugary1995 Or which part should be changed from von-mises modules? Thanks.

node.title: CavityPressure Issues
node.bodyText:
Hello,
When I used CavityPressure as the boundary condition of the gas cavity, there was a problem of non-convergence in the calculation. But when I set the cavity pressure boundary to constant pressure using Pressure,  the calculation converged. What's the problem?
Here is my input file.

init_pressure = 4.0e6 # Pa
rad_fuel = 4.096e-3 # m

node.title: Issue of Preset option in DirichletBC and Explicit Solver
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I would like to ask a possible workaround to pass aux variable (from sub app) to DirichletBC. Specifically, I have the following code to extract variable from sub app:
[Transfers]
    [pull_resid]
        type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
        from_multi_app = sub_app
        source_variable = 'disp_plusminus_sub_scaled_x'
        variable = 'disp_plusminus_scaled_x'
        execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []

where disp_plusminus_scaled_x will be enforced as DirichletBC using a custom one which basically pass variable into the BC:
  [./assignbc_primary_x]
        type = CoupledVarDirichletBC
        variable = disp_x
        preset_value = disp_plusminus_scaled_x
        boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        preset = false
  []

The current approach is to set preset=false which allows the BC to be set during the system solve (if preset = true then it will be set before TIMESTEP_BEGIN, which gives 0 in return since the aux variable hasn't received the value from sub app yet)
There are two questions:

What does preset = false do? Is it safe to use this option.
Is there a way to pass the value to BC but remain preset = true, which is the default option in Nodal BC.

Thanks in advance!

Hello


preset=true means that we enforce the value of the variable directly, and remove the dof from the equations (reducing the number of equations to solve)
false means we dont do that, and we solve an equation at the boundary
It's safe, and even necessary when enforcing the constraint (for example on a displacement) directly leads to conditioning/mesh issues


You could initialize the auxvariable to something good. Maybe from a restart file using SolutionIC ?


what is coupledVarDirichletBC? There's matchedValueBC for this


Guillaume

Thanks Guid! MatchedValueBC seems to perform the same as "weakly-enforced" boundary condition. However, I'm looking for  "strongly-enforced" boundary condition at each time step at the interface using explicit scheme. As I chatted with Peter and Alex, this may not be an easy task.

I have the following minimum script using CentralDifference and DirichletBC, but as I changed the option from preset=false to preset=true, the results are a bit weird for preset=true , could someone take a look at it? Thanks!
[Mesh]
    [./msh]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        nx = 10
        ny = 10
        xmin = -500
        xmax = 500
        ymin = -500
        ymax = 500
    [../]
    [./new_block]
        type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
        input = msh
        combinatorial_geometry = 'y<0'
        block_id = 1
    []
    #add "Block0_Block1" and "Block1_Block0" interfaces
    [./split]
        type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
        input = new_block
        split_interface = true
        add_interface_on_two_sides = true
    []
[]

[GlobalParams]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Variables]
    [./disp_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
[]

[Modules]
    [./TensorMechanics]
        [./Master]
        [./all]
            strain = SMALL
            displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
            planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
        [../]
        [../]
    [../]
[]

[Materials]
    [elasticity]
        type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        lambda = 1
        shear_modulus = 1
        use_displaced_mesh = false
    []
    [stress]
        type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    []
    [density]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = density
        prop_values = 1
    []
[]

[Kernels]
    [./inertia_x]
        type = InertialForce
        use_displaced_mesh = false
        variable = disp_x
    []
    [./inertia_y]
        type = InertialForce
        use_displaced_mesh = false
        variable = disp_y
    []
[]

[BCs]
    [./dirichlet_primary_x]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = disp_x
        boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        value = 1
        preset = false
    []
    [./dirichlet_secondary_x]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = disp_x
        boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        value = -1
        preset = false
    []
    [./dirichlet_primary_y]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = disp_y
        boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        value = 0
        preset = false
    []
    [./dirichlet_secondary_y]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = disp_y
        boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        value = 0
        preset = false
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    dt = 1
    num_steps = 1
    [TimeIntegrator]
        type = CentralDifference
        solve_type = lumped
    []
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    interval = 1
[]

preset=false gives desired results, the interface displaces 1.

preset=true gives weird results, the interface displaces 0, while the interior nodes displaces 0.0001 (seems to me like 1 / (100 * 100), where 100 is the element length), which is not going to happen for explicit scheme with lumped mass option, something is wrong here.
central difference doesn't work with preset=true
Thanks Gary!
Is there an issue for this?

So the algorithm we follow separates the evaluations on the interface and set the outcome interface displacement as strong Dirichlet BC, the preset=false weakly enforces the value which may or may not contributes to the mismatch issue I'm facing.

I am pretty sure that i am missing certain modules here that are vital in bridging these entities together. Could anybody advise me on the right way to address the material behaviour for the problems one might enounter in crsytal plasticity simulations in the context of a RVE model solved by a global strain approach?
Kind regards,
Arun

Hi Arun,
We'd recommend that you use the newer material-based Compute Multiple Crystal Plasticity Stress system. The material constitutive model, Crystal Plasticity Kalidini Update will replicate the functionality used in your input file. The ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress system is being actively developed while the FiniteStrainCrystalPlasticity is not.
With any of our MOOSE crystal plasticity classes, one must supply an incremental strain calculator class, usually ComputeFiniteStrain. The error you are seeing occurs because only the incremental strain calculator classes provide the deformation gradient, and ComputeSmallStrain is a total strain calculator class which does not compute a deformation gradient. Please see the regression test input file here as an example.
I would also recommend the use of the TensorMechanicsMaster action, if it will work well with the GlobalStrain. @SudiptaBiswas  and @dschwen  would you please provide guidance here?
Best Regards,
Stephanie
GlobalStrain approach works with TensormechanicsMasterAction. Here is an example, https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/global_strain/global_strain_action.i.

Hi Arun,
Only a couple of quick modifications to your input file ought to be all that's required to get your simulation running:

Remove the entire strain block, because this class is created by the TensorMechanics master action

[./strain]
  type = ComputeFiniteStrain
  block = 0
  displacements = 'u_x u_y u_z'
[../]


Change the strain setting in the TensorMechanics master action from strain = SMALL to strain = FINITE. This modification will create the ComputeFiniteStrain class from 1. automatically

Best Regards,
Stephanie
